Under the MoU, TruAlt Bioenergy will invest approximately Rs.
Sustainable Aviation Fuel is no longer a future possibility; it is an urgent global necessity.
We are honoured to partner with the Government of Andhra Pradesh in advancing this national and global decarbonisation mandate,” he added.
text:
TruAlt Bioenergy Limited (TruAlt), one of India’s largest and fastest-growing biofuels producers, today announced the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Andhra Pradesh Economic Development Board (APEDB) to develop one of the world’s largest Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production facilities in the State of Andhra Pradesh. The proposed 80,000 TPA facility will be located around the Srikakulam–Vizianagaram region of Andhra Pradesh.

Under the MoU, TruAlt Bioenergy will invest approximately Rs. 2,250 crore to establish an integrated ethanol-to-SAF manufacturing facility. The proposed plant is expected to create over 500 direct jobs and nearly 2,000 indirect jobs, catalysing substantial economic growth across allied sectors and contributing to the region’s industrial expansion and employment generation.

TruAlt will also leverage its position as India’s largest ethanol producer to secure reliable, high-quality feedstock and drive efficient, large-scale SAF production through the Alcohol-to-Jet Synthetic Paraffinic Kerosene (ATJ-SPK) pathway, one of the certified and approved routes under the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) framework.

In this pathway, any sugar-based feedstock is converted into ethanol, which is then upgraded into aviation-grade jet fuel. By adopting this technology, TruAlt will produce low-emission, internationally certified SAF and enable a scalable, dependable and globally competitive supply chain built on India’s abundant agricultural and bio-based resources.

Speaking on this milestone, Vijay Nirani, Managing Director, TruAlt Bioenergy, said, “This MoU marks a defining moment in India’s clean-energy transition and in TruAlt Bioenergy’s journey of innovation and impact. Sustainable Aviation Fuel is no longer a future possibility; it is an urgent global necessity. By establishing one of the world’s largest ethanol-to-SAF facilities in Andhra Pradesh, we are taking a decisive step toward enabling low-carbon aviation at scale in one of the world’s most hard-to-abate sectors.”

“India has already set a mandate for blending SAF into aviation turbine fuel, and we look forward to playing a vital role in helping the nation achieve this target. As India’s largest ethanol producer, we are uniquely positioned to integrate our feedstock strength with world-class ATJ-SPK technology and build a reliable, future-ready SAF ecosystem. We are honoured to partner with the Government of Andhra Pradesh in advancing this national and global decarbonisation mandate,” he added.

outlet: Indian Aerospace and Defence Bulletin - News for aerospace and defence in India
title: Flying Toward A Sustainable Future: Aviation's Journey To Net-Zero Carbon By 2050
description:
But the good news is that the aviation industry is already charting a course toward a cleaner, greener future.
Sustainable aviation fuels (SAFs), hailed as a game-changer, are still produced in limited quantities.
Yet, these challenges make the journey toward sustainable aviation all the more thrilling.
Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAFs) have emerged as a promising bridge toward a cleaner aviation future.
Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) is one of the most promising tools in this effort.
text:
Chaitali Bag

The world is on the move—literally. Air travel connects continents, fuels global commerce, and brings people closer together than ever before. Yet, with international air passenger numbers projected to nearly double over the next two decades, aviation faces one of the most exciting and urgent challenges in its history: how to grow sustainably while drastically cutting carbon emissions. The industry’s bold goal to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 is not just ambitious—it’s revolutionary.

The stakes could not be higher. As passenger numbers soar, fuel consumption may climb to an astounding 370 million gallons per day. Without decisive action, aviation-related emissions could rise by 40% by 2040. This forecast underscores the need for immediate innovation and global collaboration. But the good news is that the aviation industry is already charting a course toward a cleaner, greener future. From industry leaders to policymakers and engineers, a shared commitment to decarbonization is energizing the skies.

Aviation and the Race Against Climate Change: Charting a New Flight Path to Net Zero

Aviation has always symbolized human progress, connecting people and economies across the globe. Yet, the very industry that unites us is now facing a turbulent challenge—its growing contribution to climate change. From the steady plume of carbon dioxide (CO₂) emissions to the fleeting but potent influence of short-lived climate pollutants (SLCPs), the aviation sector stands at the intersection of innovation, sustainability, and urgency. The need for decisive action has never been more apparent, nor more exciting.

In 2022, the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) made a bold commitment: achieving net-zero CO₂ emissions by 2050. This target echoes the global ambition set out in the Paris Agreement—to limit warming well below 2°C, while striving to stay within the 1.5°C threshold. However, current trends indicate that aviation is not on track to meet that goal. Fuel efficiency improvements are progressing, but not fast enough. Sustainable aviation fuels (SAFs), hailed as a game-changer, are still produced in limited quantities. And while electric and hydrogen-powered aircraft spark enthusiasm, they remain primarily in development stages. The message is clear: ambition must now transform into acceleration.

But there’s a silver lining piercing through this complex cloud layer. Scientists are deepening our understanding of non-CO₂ climate effects from aviation, particularly the role of SLCPs such as nitrogen oxides, black carbon, and the mesmerizing but problematic contrail cirrus—those white streaks across the sky that can trap heat in the atmosphere. Recent research suggests that controlling these short-lived pollutants could bring relatively rapid climate benefits. For instance, contrail mitigation strategies—altering flight paths, adjusting altitudes, or developing cleaner combustion technologies—could cool the planet in the short term while longer-term CO₂ reduction technologies mature.

Despite this promising outlook, current aviation decarbonization roadmaps do not yet fully incorporate SLCP controls. This gap represents not a failure, but an opportunity. Integrating SLCP management into aviation’s net-zero strategy could significantly accelerate climate progress, providing a bridge between today’s emissions reality and tomorrow’s cleaner skies.

To put the challenge into perspective, the world’s remaining “warming budget” to stay within 1.7°C is shrinking rapidly. Studies warn that global temperatures may exceed 1.5°C before 2030—an alarm bell for every sector, including aviation. If the industry continues its current trajectory without deep innovation and coordinated global policy, its share of the climate burden will only grow. Yet, the aviation community has something powerful on its side: ingenuity. From the Wright brothers’ first flight to the jet age, aviation has proven that bold vision, science, and determination can transform the impossible into the achievable.

Reimagining aviation for a net-zero future is not just an environmental responsibility—it is a call to action for engineers, policymakers, and travellers alike. Every new aircraft design, every liter of sustainable fuel, and every rerouted contrail brings us closer to a future where the skies remain open, blue, and climate safe. The task is immense, but the opportunity is exhilarating. Aviation’s next great leap will not only be across continents—it will be toward a stable and sustainable planet.

Propelling Aerospace Toward a Cleaner Tomorrow: The Bold Journey to Net-Zero Flight!

The quest to decarbonize the aerospace industry is one of the most ambitious and inspiring challenges of our time. While other sectors have made rapid progress toward net-zero goals, aviation stands apart—flying high, quite literally, on the wings of immense technical complexity, safety imperatives, and energy demands. Yet, these challenges make the journey toward sustainable aviation all the more thrilling. The industry’s goal to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 isn’t just an aspiration—it’s a moonshot that embodies human ingenuity, persistence, and the relentless spirit of innovation.

Aviation is inherently energy-intensive. Flying an aircraft at 35,000 feet and speeds surpassing 600 miles per hour requires an energy-to-weight ratio that very few materials or fuels can offer. Today, fossil-based jet fuel remains the only energy source capable of meeting these extreme performance demands at a competitive cost. Unfortunately, this dependence comes at a significant environmental price. Burning jet fuel emits vast amounts of carbon dioxide and other pollutants, contributing to global climate change. The world urgently needs an alternative, but replacing jet fuel is no simple task.

Achieving Net-Zero: The Trillion-Dollar Journey to Transform Aviation

Reaching net-zero emissions by mid-century is not just a matter of ambition—it’s the defining challenge and opportunity of our generation. The aviation industry sits at the heart of this transformation, a sector that connects the world yet relies heavily on fossil fuels. To achieve true sustainability, industry leaders, governments, and innovators must come together to invest over a trillion dollars in the next two decades. This monumental commitment will fuel the evolution of new technologies, reshape business models, and redefine what flight means in a greener future.

At the center of this transition lies Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), which currently accounts for only 0.3% of global jet fuel use. That statistic alone emphasizes the uphill battle ahead. To close the gap between aspiration and reality, SAF production must scale exponentially. This won’t happen naturally or easily; it will require a symphony of global cooperation, with governments implementing forward-looking regulations, creating economic incentives, and ensuring that early adopters of sustainable solutions are not left at a disadvantage. Industry stakeholders must also innovate relentlessly, improving feedstock efficiency, building scalable supply chains, and driving down costs through technology and volume. The success of SAF will be measured not only in gallons produced but in the industry’s ability to make it a mainstream, economically viable alternative to conventional jet fuel.

Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAFs) have emerged as a promising bridge toward a cleaner aviation future. These fuels can reduce lifecycle emissions by up to 70–80% compared to conventional jet fuel—a significant step in the right direction. However, the road to scalable adoption is steep. High production costs, limited access to feedstock, and constrained production capacities have slowed the ramp-up of SAF usage. Even though global SAF production is expected to triple to about 1.9 billion liters in 2024, this figure represents a mere 0.53% of total aviation fuel demand. Clearly, the sector has a long way to go before SAFs can make a substantial dent in emissions figures.

Beyond fuels, the frontier of aircraft and propulsion technology is equally exciting—yet similarly challenging. Hydrogen, electric, and hybrid-electric propulsion systems represent a bold vision for aviation’s future, but these innovations remain in the early stages of development. While breakthroughs are on the horizon, they haven’t yet matured to the point of large-scale deployment. In the near term, the industry will rely on incremental gains within conventional aircraft architectures, continuing the legacy of efficiency improvements that have defined aviation progress for the past 6 decades. Remarkably, every central new aircraft platform since the dawn of the jet age has improved fuel efficiency by about 15%. With ongoing research in aerodynamics, lightweight materials, and engine thermodynamics, there is confidence that the next-generation aircraft—likely entering service around 2034—can achieve similar gains.

However, the intricacies of the industry’s economics add layers of complexity. The typical aircraft development timeline spans eight to ten years, with several more years required to reach peak production. Moreover, the business model for aircraft and propulsion systems relies heavily on long-term aftermarket revenue—often peaking 10 to 15 years after a plane enters service. This means that even if a revolutionary new aircraft were introduced today, its actual market impact would stretch well into the 2040s. In this context, the idea of completely replacing fleets with zero-emission technologies by 2050 becomes practically impossible unless the industry accelerates its readiness for scaled transition technologies right now.

Despite these challenges, the tone of the future is remarkably optimistic. The pathway to net-zero is not one of despair—it’s one of discovery. Industry-wide collaboration, bold investments, and supportive public policy will drive technological evolution at an unprecedented pace. Every dollar invested today in clean energy research, SAF production, and next-generation propulsion moves us closer to an aviation system that connects humanity sustainably.

Re-Capturing Carbon: Paving the Path to Aviation’s Sustainable Future

The aviation industry stands at a thrilling crossroads—where innovation meets responsibility, and ambition embraces environmental stewardship. As airlines continue their journey toward a sustainable sky, the bold challenge that lies ahead is clear: to recapture all the carbon dioxide that cannot yet be avoided. This mission is not simply about offsetting emissions; it is about transforming the very foundation of how we fly.

In the near to mid-term, aircraft will inevitably continue to rely on conventional fossil-based aviation fuels. Despite rapid progress in developing sustainable alternatives, the global fleet cannot transition overnight. Many promising replacements—such as sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) derived from waste materials or synthetic sources—have the potential to reduce net emissions during flight significantly. However, even these advanced fuels are not entirely free of carbon impact; their manufacture and transport still leave a trace of CO₂ behind. Therefore, to truly achieve climate neutrality, the sector must invest vigorously in atmospheric carbon capture technologies and robust, verifiable carbon offset mechanisms.

This is where the International Air Transport Association’s (IATA) Net Zero Roadmaps come into play. These five detailed and dynamic roadmaps outline a path toward net-zero emissions by 2050—a monumental goal that demands collaboration among scientists, engineers, policymakers, financiers, and operators worldwide. They represent more than a plan; they are a vision for an aviation ecosystem where every technological advancement, infrastructural investment, operational improvement, and financial model contributes coherently to a sustainable outcome.

What makes these roadmaps particularly inspiring is their adaptability. They acknowledge that the industry’s trajectory will evolve as research deepens and discoveries emerge. Progress in aircraft design, cleaner energy production, optimized flight operations, and supportive government policies will create a symphony of innovation that reshapes our understanding of flight. The journey to sustainable aviation is not linear—it’s an evolving exploration guided by creativity, determination, and global cooperation.

Re-capturing unavoidable carbon is both a technological challenge and a moral imperative. It calls upon the brightest minds to develop scalable carbon removal methods, from direct air capture facilities to nature-based restoration projects. The excitement lies in the possibility: a world where flying no longer contributes to climate change, but instead participates in a balanced, restorative cycle of energy and environment.

The Aircraft Technology Roadmap by IATA stands as a bold, visionary blueprint guiding the aviation industry toward a brilliantly sustainable future —one where technological innovation takes flight toward net-zero emissions! At its core, this roadmap addresses one of the most pressing challenges in aviation—fuel burn and its carbon footprint—by defining how cutting-edge aircraft and engine technologies can achieve revolutionary leaps in energy efficiency. Imagine jet-fuelled aircraft that are 15–20% more efficient than today’s best designs, saving up to 140 million tonnes of CO₂ by 2050 and slashing the sector’s in-flight energy needs by nearly a tenth! These next-generation aircraft will be designed to seamlessly operate on 100% Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF), marking a monumental stride in decarbonizing air travel. But the transformation does not stop there—visionary breakthroughs in hydrogen propulsion and electric aircraft promise to propel the industry into an age of zero-emission flight, potentially avoiding an additional 35–125 million tonnes of CO₂, depending on how rapidly these game-changing technologies conquer the skies. Supported by substantial investments and ongoing demonstrator programs in areas such as advanced aerodynamics, aircraft structures, propulsion systems, and intelligent flight controls, each advancement will progress through the TRL scale —from experimental trials to exhilarating first flights and finally to commercial service.

Meanwhile, the Energy and New Fuels Infrastructure Roadmap is laying the groundwork for a massive expansion in SAF production, calling for thousands of new biorefineries and a vast hydrogen network that could redefine global energy flows. By 2050, SAF is expected to account for nearly 90% of aviation fuel, reducing emissions by an astounding 62%, while carbon capture facilities extract over 700 million tonnes of CO₂ from the atmosphere, closing the loop. All of this will be powered by abundant, renewable energy sources, transforming not just aircraft, but the entire aviation ecosystem into a cleaner, smarter, and more inspiring engine of human progress. The future of flight has never looked more promising—innovation, sustainability, and ambition soaring together toward a net-zero horizon!

The global aviation industry is standing at a defining crossroads. As the world accelerates its pursuit of sustainability, air traffic management (ATM) and operations must evolve to meet an undeniably urgent challenge: achieving net—zero CO₂ emissions by 2050. The Operations Roadmap and its partner initiative, the Finance Roadmap, together form an inspiring, action-oriented blueprint for this transformation. They show us that sustainable civil aviation is not just a lofty ambition but a tangible, achievable goal—if we act collaboratively, decisively, and intelligently.

Operations lie at the very heart of aviation’s sustainability journey. Air Traffic Management, as an essential component of national infrastructure, must be prioritized in every strategic conversation about sustainable aviation. It is more than just coordinating airplanes in the sky—it is the nervous system of global aviation, influencing efficiency, fuel use, and ultimately, emissions. Yet today’s ATM systems are riddled with inefficiencies that waste fuel and generate unnecessary CO₂. The exciting truth is that solving these inefficiencies doesn’t require waiting for tomorrow’s technologies—progress can begin *now*. Through smarter routing, better coordination, and more intelligent resource use, operations can deliver meaningful near-term emission reductions.

However, operational improvements can only achieve their full potential through strong alignment and shared vision. Airlines, airports, and Air Navigation Service Providers (ANSPs) must synchronize their investment plans and implementation timelines. Without this integration, even the most advanced ATM programs will struggle to deliver on their promises. Airspace is both a scarce and shared resource, and its effective management demands joint stewardship. By fostering partnerships among stakeholders, the industry can turn local progress into global transformation.

The roadmap identifies several exciting strategies to accelerate progress. Local and regional projects can serve as “proof of concept,” showing the real-world benefits of innovative technologies and operational methods, and helping shape global standards. Benchmarking environmental and performance outcomes will track progress, spotlight best practices, and promote the transition toward Trajectory-Based Operations (TBO)—a more innovative, more predictable way to manage flight paths. Furthermore, regional consortia can ensure that the unique needs of airspace users are respected throughout the planning and implementation phases. Collaboration, transparency, and innovation become the fuel for progress.

The Finance Roadmap, updated in September 2024, complements this operational vision by quantifying the investments required to reach net-zero emissions. Its message is clear: achieving sustainability demands not only technological and procedural innovation but also bold financial commitment. The required average annual investment—around USD 128 billion per year until 2050—may sound enormous. Still, it is far less than what the world has already invested in renewable energy markets like solar and wind. This comparison underscores both the feasibility and necessity of the aviation sector’s transition. Governments also have a crucial role to play: redirecting subsidies from fossil fuels to renewable energy production can accelerate this process dramatically, especially in the scaling of Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF).

The Economics team’s projections remind us of the magnitude and urgency of the task. Transition costs—estimated at USD 1.4 billion in 2025 and potentially rising to USD 744 billion by 2050—underline the need for speed, innovation, and scale. Every year of delay increases both the financial and environmental costs. Yet with unified purpose and wise investment, the aviation industry can turn these challenges into opportunities—creating a cleaner, more resilient ecosystem that benefits not just airlines, but all of society.

Adding to the complexity are structural characteristics unique to aviation. Aircraft have incredibly long lifespans—often flying safely for 20 to 30 years. This extended service life is an engineering marvel, but also means that replacing or upgrading airline fleets with newer, cleaner models happens at a measured pace. Furthermore, each aircraft must undergo rigorous certification to meet strict safety and performance standards. These certification processes, while essential, can take a decade or more, delaying the adoption of cutting-edge technology. This ensures public safety but slows innovation cycles compared to other industries.

The Green Sky Race Takes Off: Global Push to Supercharge Sustainable Aviation Fuels

The global race to scale up sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production is on, and it’s nothing short of exhilarating! Current project pipelines fall far short of what’s needed—we must multiply capacity by five to six times before 2030 to keep the aviation industry on track for net-zero emissions by 2050. That means bringing both bio-based jet fuels and power-to-liquid (PtL) fuels to market fast, with investments in 300–400 new production plants and supportive infrastructure. The timeline is tight—since it takes at least 5 years to build and commission a SAF plant, planning must begin within the next 2 to 3 years. Clever policy design will be essential, prioritizing sustainable biomass for aviation and leveraging the upcoming electrification of road transport to redirect ethanol toward jet fuel via the alcohol-to-jet process. Combined with optimization of existing HEFA plants to produce more jet fuel, these actions could deliver an additional 14–22 Mt of SAF by 2030—covering up to half of projected demand.

The race to decarbonize aviation is on, and the pace of progress in renewable electricity costs will shape which sustainable fuels take the lead! If renewable power prices drop quickly, Power-to-Liquid (PtL) fuels—produced using renewable electricity and green hydrogen—are poised to soar, capturing a dominant market share by 2050 as outlined in the optimistic ORE scenario. This rapid decline in electricity costs would make green hydrogen and PtL production far more affordable, eventually outcompeting biofuels. However, if renewable power becomes cheaper more slowly, biofuels will remain the frontrunners, provided that sufficient sustainable biomass is available, which underpins the PRU scenario. In reality, the skies of the future will likely be powered by a blend of solutions—biofuels, PtL, and hydrogen—working together to push aviation toward a cleaner, more sustainable future!

By the late 2030s, hydrogen and battery-electric aircraft are poised to transform global aviation, paving the way for cleaner, more efficient skies. Hydrogen-powered planes could debut around 2035 and soar in market share through 2050, supplying up to one-third of aviation’s total energy demand if range and storage breakthroughs continue. Though early models may be limited to roughly 2,500 kilometers due to hydrogen’s lower energy density, innovation in airframe design and fuel storage could soon unlock longer routes without sacrificing passenger capacity. Meanwhile, advances in battery chemistries are opening new horizons for fully electric aircraft, making regional flights up to 1,000 kilometers feasible by mid-century. While electric planes might replace over 15% of the global fleet, their impact on emissions will complement hydrogen’s broader potential. The first step toward this sustainable revolution lies in “green corridors”—dedicated routes between airports equipped for refuelling and recharging—ushering in a new era of cleaner, smarter, and more sustainable aviation.

Flying Into the Future

Achieving this transformation will require much more than incremental improvements. It calls for a sweeping overhaul of technology, infrastructure, and operational practices. Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) is one of the most promising tools in this effort. Derived from renewable sources like waste oils and agricultural residues, SAF can reduce lifecycle carbon emissions by up to 80% compared to conventional jet fuel. To meet future demand, however, production must be scaled up massively—an exciting opportunity for innovation and investment worldwide.

Equally transformative are new technologies such as hydrogen-powered and electric aircraft. Green hydrogen, generated using renewable electricity, could power short-haul flights while producing only water as a byproduct. Electric propulsion, though still in its infancy for commercial aviation, promises silent, zero-emission operations for regional routes. Airports, too, will play a crucial role, evolving into hubs of clean energy complete with charging and hydrogen fuelling infrastructure.

Policy and collaboration will be just as important as technology. Governments, manufacturers, airlines, and fuel producers must coordinate to create incentives, establish clear regulatory frameworks, and invest in research and infrastructure. Incremental progress is already visible: modern aircraft are 80% more fuel-efficient than the first generation of airliners and emit 50% less CO₂ than those flying in 1990. Each new aircraft design improves fuel efficiency by an impressive 15–25%, proving that innovation is part of aviation’s DNA.

The journey to net-zero will not be easy, but it will be exhilarating. It represents an unprecedented opportunity to reinvent an industry that has always symbolized human progress and possibility. By combining visionary technology, sustainable fuels, robust policies, and a spirit of global cooperation, aviation can continue to connect the world—this time, with a lighter footprint and a brighter future. The sky is not just the limit; it’s the beginning of a sustainable revolution in flight.

As the aviation sector charts its course to 2050, one thing is sure—the dream of guilt-free flight is no longer science fiction. With innovation at full throttle and sustainability as its compass, the skies of tomorrow promise to be not only busier but also bluer, cleaner, and infinitely more hopeful.

title: Singapore to impose sustainable aviation fuel levy from 2026 - The Bangladesh Monitor
description:
Singapore : From October 1, 2026, air travelers departing from Singapore will pay a sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) levy ranging from SD 1 to SD 41.60 per ticket, depending on flight distance and travel class, the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) announced on November 10.
The levy will apply to tickets sold after April 1, 2026, and will help fund the purchase of SAF to cut aviation emissions.
Tickets bought before that date or for flights before October 1 will not be affected.
Airlines must collect and display the levy as a separate item on tickets.
Cargo shipments will also face a distance-based levy - from SD 0.01 to SD 0.15 per kg, while private and corporate flights will pay SD 40 to SD 6,500 depending on aircraft size and route.
text:
Singapore : From October 1, 2026, air travelers departing from Singapore will pay a sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) levy ranging from SD 1 to SD 41.60 per ticket, depending on flight distance and travel class, the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) announced on November 10.

The levy will apply to tickets sold after April 1, 2026, and will help fund the purchase of SAF to cut aviation emissions. Tickets bought before that date or for flights before October 1 will not be affected.

Destinations are grouped into four travel bands:

Band 1 (Southeast Asia): SD 1 for economy, SD 4 for premium cabins

Band 2 (Northeast & South Asia, Australia, Papua New Guinea): SD 2.80 and SD 11.20

Band 3 (Europe, Middle East, Africa, New Zealand): SD 6.40 and SD 25.60

Band 4 (Americas): SD 10.40 and SD 41.60

Transit passengers will be exempt, and the levy for multi-stop flights will depend on the next destination after Singapore. Airlines must collect and display the levy as a separate item on tickets.

Cargo shipments will also face a distance-based levy - from SD 0.01 to SD 0.15 per kg, while private and corporate flights will pay SD 40 to SD 6,500 depending on aircraft size and route. Training, humanitarian, and charity flights will be exempt.

outlet: Indian Aerospace and Defence Bulletin - News for aerospace and defence in India
title: Boeing & India Soar Higher Together: A Visionary Partnership Powering The Future Of ...
description:
Chaitali Bag Boeing’s deepening collaboration with India is a testament to the visionary power of partnerships to propel global aerospace innovation to new heights!
A. Boeing’s commitment to developing India’s aerospace talent ecosystem is long-standing.
Partnerships are crucial for supporting India’s aviation growth while improving operational efficiency and ensuring safety.
In 2023, we shipped the first 737 vertical fin from our joint-venture facility, Tata Boeing Aerospace Limited (TBAL) in Hyderabad.
Boeing will continue investing in local manufacturing, co-production, co-development, skill building, and innovation to strengthen India’s aerospace, defence, and commercial aviation ecosystem.
text:
Chaitali Bag

Boeing’s deepening collaboration with India is a testament to the visionary power of partnerships to propel global aerospace innovation to new heights! As the company strengthens its local MRO capabilities through initiatives like the Boeing India Repair Development and Sustainment (BIRDS) program and continues nurturing talent through programs such as BUILD and the Sukanya initiative, India’s aerospace and defence ecosystem is poised for extraordinary growth as Indian Aerospace & Defence gets exclusive insights from Salil Gupte, President, Boeing India & South Asia on its longstanding zero-tariff commitment and decades of engagement in India that perfectly align with the nation’s ambitious Aatmanirbhar Bharat agenda, fostering self-reliance while nurturing global excellence. In an era marked by evolving trade dynamics and expanding strategic ties between India and the United States, such collaborations promise a future where advanced technological exchange, entrepreneurship, and sustainability drive a resilient aerospace industry—one that not only takes flight but soars beyond boundaries!

Q. In light of Boeing’s expanding engagement with India’s manufacturing sector and its long-standing commitment to maintaining a zero-tariff environment in aerospace and defence since 1979, how might future collaborations between Indian enterprises and global aerospace companies evolve, particularly in the context of shifting geopolitical dynamics and ongoing trade negotiations between India and the United States?

A. Boeing’s manufacturing and engineering footprint remains largely based in the U.S., and so naturally, the U.S. is the cornerstone of our global operations. At the same time, the unique talent and supply chain capabilities in international markets, including India, serve local needs and also enhance our global capabilities, driving advancements for Boeing and the industry. The Joint Statement of President Trump and Prime Minister Modi from earlier this year actually called out the opportunities for collaboration in this regard, as both countries continue to see tremendous potential in working together on industrial development for aerospace & defence. Given Boeing’s eight decades of presence in India, we remain committed to working with local partners, investing in talent development, and meeting the needs of the nation for an aerospace and defence ecosystem.

Q. How have Boeing’s initiatives, such as the Boeing University Innovation Leadership Development (BUILD) program and earlier efforts like the Boeing HorizonX India Innovation Challenge and the Accelerated Aircraft Maintenance Engineers Apprenticeship program, contributed to fostering innovation, entrepreneurship, and skill development within India’s aerospace and defence industry?

A. Boeing’s commitment to developing India’s aerospace talent ecosystem is long-standing. Initiatives such as the Boeing University Innovation Leadership Development (BUILD) program have helped connect young innovators, entrepreneurs, and startups to real-world aerospace challenges, fostering a culture of co-creation and entrepreneurial thinking. The Accelerated Aircraft Maintenance Engineers Apprenticeship program builds hands-on capabilities for high-demand roles in aviation services. The Boeing Sukanya Program, launched in 2024 by the Hon’ble Prime Minister of India, promotes women’s participation in aviation through STEM labs, digital skills, and pilot training. The Kaushal initiative supports differently abled individuals and underserved youth with certified training in aircraft maintenance. At the same time, the Veterans Skilling Program has trained over 22,000 ex-servicemen and their families for civilian careers in aerospace. Together, these initiatives reflect Boeing’s long-standing approach: connecting young talent to real-world aerospace challenges and enabling participation. Boeing is helping shape a future-ready workforce that supports India’s journey of aerospace and defence industrialization.

Q. To what extent can Boeing’s initiative to encourage its component suppliers to establish maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) facilities in India be expected to strengthen the country’s aviation ecosystem, and how might this align with India’s broader policy of promoting domestic MRO capabilities through liberalized foreign direct investment and expanding airport infrastructure?

A. Boeing’s efforts to localize Maintenance, Repair, and Overhaul (MRO) capabilities in India are central to its long-term strategy of supporting operational efficiency, economic growth, and self-reliance across the aviation ecosystem. The Boeing India Repair Development and Sustainment (BIRDS) program is a cornerstone of this approach, designed to build a robust MRO infrastructure for both defence and commercial platforms. By combining resources across civil and defence sectors, BIRDS enhances cost-effectiveness, reduces turnaround times, and introduces advanced defence technologies into civil aviation, fostering innovation across both domains.

These efforts directly support India’s Aatmanirbhar Bharat vision. Boeing’s in-country development includes state-of-the-art facilities such as the C-17 MRO and training center at Hindon and the P-8I training facility at Rajali, which ensure operational readiness and set industry benchmarks for excellence. The program also creates high-skilled jobs, attracts foreign investment, and fosters the growth of Micro, Small & Medium Enterprises (MSMEs). Where more work remains is in component and engine MRO. That’s why Boeing is actively encouraging OEM partners to deepen their footprint in India. As customs, tax, and repair-exchange norms evolve, India is well-positioned to become a regional MRO hub, retaining maintenance spend that previously flowed overseas and strengthening its aviation infrastructure.

Q. How is India’s air cargo and freighter segment expected to evolve, and which structural or market forces are influencing its growth?

A. Approximately half of the global demand for conversions is expected to come from the regions of Asia and Africa, including India. This is driven by the rapid expansion of e-commerce and the electronics manufacturing industry, which has revolutionized customer expectations and supply chain needs. Global e-commerce revenues are projected to reach more than double pre-pandemic levels by 2026, with air cargo playing a key role in emerging markets lacking well-established ground and postal networks. The rise of high-end electronics manufacturing in India, such as smartphones and wearables, along with other high-value-added manufacturing, like semiconductors, is creating opportunities for future air cargo growth.

India’s domestic air cargo trade is forecasted to continue rapid growth at 6.9% per year over the next two decades. The growth is driven by factors including the overall expansion of the Indian economy and increased demand for air cargo transportation. Furthermore, the expansion of India’s e-commerce sector is contributing to the demand for efficient and reliable logistics and transportation solutions. This has led to the entry of cargo carriers into the Indian market that are operating a range of freighters, including the Boeing 737-800 Boeing Converted Freighter, to cater to the growing demand for air cargo services.

Q. What kind of role do you see Boeing play in the growth of India’s civil aviation sector in the coming years?

A. With a partnership spanning over eight decades, Boeing is today the largest foreign OEM sourcing from India through a network of over 325 suppliers, including more than 25% MSMEs that form an integral part of our global supply chain. Supporting the Aatmanirbhar Bharat initiative is central to our long-term strategy. Partnerships are crucial for supporting India’s aviation growth while improving operational efficiency and ensuring safety. Boeing is also open to supporting India’s Regional Transport Aircraft (RTA) programme, which aims to develop a commuter aircraft with a range of 600–700 km. We see an opportunity to support advanced manufacturing to help India scale production efficiently. This initiative aligns with India’s long-term aviation and industrial ambitions and complements our broader commitment to building a robust ecosystem, including pilot training, MRO, and aerospace industrialisation. Additionally, some of the recent contributions made by Boeing include the following:

In 2025, we partnered with HPCL to help advance India’s sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) ecosystem and support the Indian Government’s environmental goals.

In 2024, in alignment with the guidance provided by the Honorable Prime Minister, Boeing initiated the Boeing Sukanya Program aimed at promoting women’s participation and leadership in aviation through STEM education and scholarships.

In 2024, Boeing set up the India Distribution Center in Khurja, Uttar Pradesh, for regional customers to maintain higher fleet utilization and mission readiness rates.

In 2023, Boeing and GMR Aero Technic are partnering to establish a new Boeing Converted Freighter line in Hyderabad. This collaboration supports cargo growth and expands aircraft modification capabilities and MRO services in India. It contributes to India’s ambition of becoming a regional MRO hub.

India is a strategically vital region for Boeing, supported by its Global Strategic Initiatives team and the establishment of a Global Support Center in Gurugram. Together, these efforts drive growth, safety, innovation, and sustainability through key programs like the India Air Cargo Symposium, India Pilot Roundtable, Executive Development Programs, Sustainability Workshops, and tailored operational efficiency projects for airline customers, regulatory bodies, and industry stakeholders.

To support the growing demand for pilots and technicians, in 2023, Boeing announced a $100 million investment in infrastructure and programs to train pilots in India, which will support India’s need for new pilots over the next 20 years.

In 2023, we shipped the first 737 vertical fin from our joint-venture facility, Tata Boeing Aerospace Limited (TBAL) in Hyderabad.

Boeing will continue investing in local manufacturing, co-production, co-development, skill building, and innovation to strengthen India’s aerospace, defence, and commercial aviation ecosystem. India remains central to Boeing’s long-term growth, driven by our commitment to safety, innovation, and sustainability.

title: EgyptAir strengthens regional role by hosting 103rd AACO executive committee
description:
Mohamed Attia EgyptAir, affirming its leading position in the Arab air transport industry and its commitment to regional collaboration, has announced it will host the 103rd Executive Committee meeting of the Arab Air Carriers Organization (AACO).
This significant event is scheduled to take place in Cairo in March 2026 and will gather the chairmen of the boards of directors of all Arab airlines that are members of the organization.
This commitment to hosting was announced during the participation of Chairman of EgyptAir Holding Company Pilot Ahmed Adel at the 102nd Executive Committee meeting held as part of the 58th AACO General Assembly in Rabat, Morocco.
During the Rabat meetings, the Executive Committee conducted comprehensive reviews of the latest developments within the air transport industry, assessing the performance of Arab airlines against international standards.
In the context of this pivotal regional role, Captain Ahmed Adel highlighted that hosting the upcoming AACO Executive Committee meeting underscores Egypt’s historical leadership and pivotal role as a vital regional hub for air transport.
text:
Mohamed Attia

EgyptAir, affirming its leading position in the Arab air transport industry and its commitment to regional collaboration, has announced it will host the 103rd Executive Committee meeting of the Arab Air Carriers Organization (AACO).

This significant event is scheduled to take place in Cairo in March 2026 and will gather the chairmen of the boards of directors of all Arab airlines that are members of the organization.

This commitment to hosting was announced during the participation of Chairman of EgyptAir Holding Company Pilot Ahmed Adel at the 102nd Executive Committee meeting held as part of the 58th AACO General Assembly in Rabat, Morocco.

During the Rabat meetings, the Executive Committee conducted comprehensive reviews of the latest developments within the air transport industry, assessing the performance of Arab airlines against international standards.

A primary focus of the discussion was the most prominent challenges facing the sector globally, particularly issues related to supply chain constraints, environmental regulations, and the path to achieving long-term sustainability.

The Committee collectively stressed the critical importance of cooperation among Arab governments to provide actionable solutions.

These solutions aim to contribute meaningfully to environmental sustainability goals and the development of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) without imposing undue financial burdens on carriers, which could otherwise negatively affect profitability or the sector’s vital contribution to the Arab GDP.

In the context of this pivotal regional role, Captain Ahmed Adel highlighted that hosting the upcoming AACO Executive Committee meeting underscores Egypt’s historical leadership and pivotal role as a vital regional hub for air transport.

He noted that this step embodies EgyptAir’s firm commitment to supporting AACO’s mission to enhance coordination and integration among Arab airlines, thereby raising their competitiveness on the global stage.

Adel anticipated that the 103rd meeting will facilitate in-depth strategic discussions on shared challenges and the future trajectory of the industry, particularly in areas like digital transformation, environmental sustainability, and operational safety.

He concluded by expressing the conviction that joint technological cooperation is the necessary guarantee for Arab airlines to reach the highest levels of operational efficiency and global competitiveness, viewing constructive Arab action as the optimal path toward sustainable development and prosperity for the region’s aviation sector.

title: XCF Global Expands Leadership Team for Sustainable Aviation Fuel Growth
description:
Effective November 7, 2025, Chris Cooper joins XCF as Chief Executive Officer (“CEO”) and Board Director.
“Joining XCF at such a transformative moment for both aviation and renewable fuels is an honor,” stated Chris Cooper.
“The demand for SAF is rapidly increasing; our modular facility design positions us well to meet this need effectively.
Additionally, Randy Soule will serve closely with Mr. Cooper as Senior Operations Adviser at XCF’s New Rise Reno facility.
“I am thrilled about Chris stepping into this leadership role,” said Randy Soule.
text:
Chris Cooper, an experienced leader in energy transition, takes on the role of Chief Executive Officer and Board Director

Wray Thorn, a current member of the XCF Board, steps in as Interim Board Chair to steer strategy and growth initiatives

Randy Soule, founder of New Rise Renewables, will collaborate with Mr. Cooper as Senior Operations Adviser

XCF Global, Inc. (“XCF”) (Nasdaq: SAFX), recognized for its commitment to decarbonizing aviation through Sustainable Aviation Fuel (“SAF”), has announced significant leadership changes aimed at refining its strategic direction and accelerating growth.

Effective November 7, 2025, Chris Cooper joins XCF as Chief Executive Officer (“CEO”) and Board Director. With a robust background in energy transition management-previously serving as President of Neste U.S., where he oversaw operations for one of the largest renewable fuel producers-Cooper brings invaluable experience from his roles at Phillips 66 and Chevron. He succeeds Mihir Dange who led XCF since November 2023.

“Joining XCF at such a transformative moment for both aviation and renewable fuels is an honor,” stated Chris Cooper. “The demand for SAF is rapidly increasing; our modular facility design positions us well to meet this need effectively. I am dedicated to enhancing operational performance while advancing our mission to reduce carbon emissions in air travel.”

Citing these developments, Wray Thorn has been appointed Interim Board Chair following Dange’s departure from that role. Thorn will concentrate on driving strategic growth initiatives within the company.

“We are excited about Chris joining us during this crucial phase,” remarked Wray Thorn. “His extensive experience in scaling renewable fuel operations aligns perfectly with our goals for expansion within the SAF market.” He also expressed gratitude towards Mihir Dange for his contributions during his tenure that included taking XCF public on Nasdaq.

Additionally, Randy Soule will serve closely with Mr. Cooper as Senior Operations Adviser at XCF’s New Rise Reno facility. As a key shareholder and founder of New Rise Renewables, Soule’s technical expertise will be instrumental in ensuring operational excellence moving forward.

“I am thrilled about Chris stepping into this leadership role,” said Randy Soule. “His track record combined with our team’s capabilities sets up XCF well for future success.”

The financial helm remains steady under Simon Oxley’s guidance as Chief Financial Officer; he brings over two decades of experience across finance and energy sectors which complements Mr. Cooper’s leadership style perfectly-together they aim to unlock new avenues for growth while maximizing shareholder value.

title: Overcapacity, margin squeeze and consolidation stare at India's booming solar equipment industry
description:
India’s solar manufacturing engine has raced ahead in the past decade — but it is heading into a roadblock - the problem of plenty.
From a modest 2.3 gigawatt (GW) of solar module capacity in 2014, the country now boasts 109 GW of capacity, supported by 100 manufacturers and 123 production units.
The Problem of Plenty Industry projections indicate that India’s module capacity will touch 130 GW and cell capacity 35 GW by March 2026.
Seven large players today control nearly half of India’s installed module capacity, and that share is likely to rise as smaller players come under pressure.
Modules made with domestic cells cost 3–4 cents per watt more than those made with imported cells.
text:
India’s solar manufacturing engine has raced ahead in the past decade — but it is heading into a roadblock - the problem of plenty. From a modest 2.3 gigawatt (GW) of solar module capacity in 2014, the country now boasts 109 GW of capacity, supported by 100 manufacturers and 123 production units. Yet this rapid expansion is now running into the hard reality of demand. With annual solar installations expected to be only 45–50 GW - against 60–65 GW of available module production - the industry is staring straight at an overcapacity issue, say experts.

A fast-growing domestic solar industry

Until 2014, India depended almost entirely on China for solar cells and modules to meet its ambition of reaching 500 GW of renewable energy capacity by 2030. A series of policy interventions under Atma Nirbhar Bharat — the Approved List of Models and Manufacturers (ALMM), which almost blocked imports, basic customs duties on imported modules and cells, and the production-linked incentive (PLI) scheme, changed the domestic industry landscape.

The ALMM order came into force in January 2019. When the first list was published in March 2021, India had just 8.2 GW of enlisted module capacity across 21 manufacturers. In just over four years, this surged more than twelvefold to 100 GW of ALMM-listed capacity, with the number of manufacturers rising nearly fivefold to 100, with 123 manufacturing units.

Fortune India Latest Edition is Out Now!

India’s Best CEOs

November 2025

The annual Fortune India special issue of India’s Best CEOs celebrates leaders who have transformed their businesses while navigating an uncertain environment, leading from the front.

Read Now

As of September 2025, India’s manufacturing base stands at 109 GW of modules and 17.9 GW of cells — one of the fastest build-outs globally. And yet, the expansion continues.

The Problem of Plenty

Industry projections indicate that India’s module capacity will touch 130 GW and cell capacity 35 GW by March 2026. By March 2027, capacities may reach 165 GW for modules and 70 GW for cells. The implementation of ALMM List-II for solar PV cells from June 2026 has fuelled further investments in cell lines by module makers.

“Cell manufacturing capacity is likely to grow to about 100 GW by December 2027, from 17.9 GW currently under ALMM,” notes rating agency ICRA.

Domestic installation demand — at 45–50 GW per year — simply cannot absorb the 60–65 GW of modules rolling off production lines annually. And with the recent US tariffs redirecting exports back to India, the domestic glut is worsening, say sources.

On the Cusp of Consolidation

ICRA expects overcapacity to squeeze margins and accelerate consolidation among the country’s 100-odd OEMs. Seven large players today control nearly half of India’s installed module capacity, and that share is likely to rise as smaller players come under pressure.

“The operating profitability of domestic solar OEMs, which stayed elevated at 25% in FY2025, is set to moderate due to competitive pressures and overcapacity,” says Ankit Jain, Vice President & Co-Group Head, Corporate Ratings, ICRA.

Adding to their challenges is the increase in uncertainty in the US — a key export market — following new tariff measures. The redirection of shipments to India is likely to intensify price competition further.

There’s also a cost disadvantage. Modules made with domestic cells cost 3–4 cents per watt more than those made with imported cells. While modules using imported cells land at around 16 cents/W, domestically sourced cells push the cost to 19.5 cents/W, says the ICRA analysis.

A reprieve comes from the exemption available to projects whose bid submission deadline falls before September 1, 2025 — a 45–50 GW pipeline that will not require ALMM-listed domestic cells even after June 2026. This should support non-integrated OEMs in the near term, although bidding activity has slowed recently, observes ICRA.

Despite India’s impressive strides, China still towers over the global solar supply chain — accounting for over 90% of polysilicon and wafer, 85% of cell, and 80% of module manufacturing capacity worldwide. Indian manufacturers remain heavily dependent on imported wafers and ingots, leaving them vulnerable to geopolitical risks and supply disruptions.

Backward integration into polysilicon and wafer manufacturing demands far higher technological sophistication — and billions in capital. Building these capacities, stabilising them, and reducing China-dependence remain among the toughest challenges ahead. Already, large corporates like Reliance Industries and Adani Group are investing billions to create an entire solar equipment value chain.
